title: Who Wins in October? Teams That Don't Strike Out
summary: Advanced analytics have made strikeouts more acceptable to modern hitters who are devoted to power. But in the playoffs, they still sink you.. The Houston Astros'sudden postseason resurgence seems like an upset. Their two opponents thus far-the Minnesota Twins and Oakland Athletics-tied for the second-best record in the American League. The Astros lost more games than they won, finished in the middle of the pack in both runs and ERA and barely sneaked into the expanded postseason field.

title: Numerical Diversity Hiring Targets Attract U.S. Scrutiny
summary: Labor Department investigates federal contractors that have specific goals in diversity pledges. The U.S. Labor Department is investigating companies with federal contracts that have included specific numerical goals in their pledges to increase diversity, arguing that these resemble illegal quotas and could potentially discriminate against white applicants and other groups, according to people familiar with the matter.

title: Hospital Chain to Return $6 Billion in Pandemic Aid Ahead of Schedule
summary: HCA Healthcare said it would give back $1.6 billion of relief and repay $4.4 billion in loans it got through congressional programs. HCA Healthcare Inc., one of the nation's largest hospital chains, said it would pay back federal pandemic relief, the latest indicator of the $1 trillion hospital sector's rebound from pandemic-inspired disruption caused by suspended surgeries and widespread lockdowns.

title: Trump Suggests His Covid-19 Infection Came From Gold Star Military Families
summary: White House doctors haven't made public any theory of where he might have contracted the virus. WASHINGTON-President Trump on Thursday speculated that he contracted the coronavirus from one or more of the Gold Star families with whom he met recently, suggesting that his infection could have come from families of survivors of the combat dead who got too close.

title: The Judiciary Grabs the Census
summary: A bad John Roberts ruling is leading to more legal mischief.. Though buried by other news, a Census case is moving through the courts with significant implications for executive authority and the separation of powers. Progressive plaintiffs and the courts are trying to hijack Congressional reapportionment.

title: The Plot Against Gretchen Whitmer
summary: The recourse is the law, not violence, when a politician overreaches.. Six men have been charged by federal prosecutors for allegedly planning to kidnap Michigan Gov. Gretchen Whitmer, apparently in an insane plot against overreaching state government. Seven others, linked to a militia group, are facing state charges. The details in an FBI affidavit suggest these people were serious.

title: A Jewish Revolt Against Lockdowns
summary: Haredim take to the streets and courts against Gov. Cuomo.. Haredim, as ultra-Orthodox Jews are called, translates to "those who tremble." But as New York's leaders are learning, the Haredim tremble before God-not politicians.

title: FDR, Coronavirus and the Politics of Bravado
summary: Trump follows a predecessor's example in urging Americans not to live in fear.. To understand Donald Trump's behavior as a Covid-19 patient (leaving Walter Reed to wave at his supporters through the window of his SUV, or checking out of the hospital early and posing maskless on the White House balcony), you might liberate your mind from the distracting context of 2020 and consider two moments in history.

title: A Former Catholic Dances With the Torah
summary: For Jews, the people of the book, sacred text is more than law; it is our friend.. Stephen Dubner, a co-author of "Freakonomics," is the son of Jewish parents who converted to Catholicism and raised him in their newfound faith. Mr. Dubner's 1998 memoir, "Turbulent Souls," recounts his later return to Judaism. His turning point came when his then-girlfriend suggested that he visit a synagogue. Mr. Dubner did so reluctantly, and on arriving instantly regretted the decision, surprised by "how little it felt like Church," and feeling "like an intruder, perhaps an imposter."

title: Shear Heaven on a Brooklyn Sidewalk
summary: I finally went out for a haircut. I got one without going in.. Brooklyn, N.Y.

title: Religious Groups Sue to Block New Covid-19 Lockdown in Parts of New York
summary: New York Gov. Cuomo's order to limit size of gatherings at houses of worship is unconstitutional, lawsuits by Roman Catholic and Orthodox Jewish groups say. Religious groups filed two lawsuits Thursday challenging the constitutionality of New York Gov. Andrew Cuomo's order limiting the size of gatherings inside houses of worship in communities seeing a rise in Covid-19 cases.

title: Biden, Pence and the Wish for Normalcy
summary: Washington talks of a Democratic blowout, while the vice president reminds us of old differences.. I hear America absorbing. Quietly. Not screeching around and having fun, not stomping and shouting as you'd expect at this point in a dramatic campaign with weeks to go, not acting up and merrily pulling campaign signs from the neighbor's lawn in the dead of night. It all feels so subdued. As if people are taking it all in, coming to terms with where this is going.

title: Jerome Powell's Big Political Gamble
summary: The Fed is independent as a safeguard against fiscal indiscipline. The chairman is shirking that duty.. Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell's stock has risen steadily on Capitol Hill in recent months as he lobbied aggressively for more fiscal stimulus in the face of the pandemic. This is one "market signal" that should make everyone nervous, not that many will admit it.

title: 'The Nazi Spy Ring in America' Review: Hoover Was Furious
summary: The New York Post headline read: 'Ace G-man Bares German Conspiracy to Paralyze United States!' Anger, and a movie, followed.. It was the FBI's first major espionage case. On Feb. 14, 1938, a U.S. Army deserter named Guenther Rumrich, the Chicago-born son of a European diplomat, was arrested after trying to secure 35 blank United States passports by posing as Secretary of State Cordell Hull. British intelligence had meanwhile intercepted a letter sent to a mail drop in Scotland revealing a plot to steal the U.S. military's defense plans for the Atlantic Coast. The sender turned out to be Rumrich, who confessed to being an agent of the Abwehr, Germany's military intelligence service.

title: Sanders Haunts Biden-Harris
summary: Pence corners Harris on Biden's embrace of the Vermont senator's radical agenda.. The Plexiglas at Wednesday's vice-presidential debate made for some strange reflections. Squint hard enough, and you might even have seen the ghostly image of the evening's third, silent participant: Bernie Sanders.

title: IBM's Red Hat Deal Laid Foundation for Split of Company Into Two Pieces
summary: 'Red Hat gave us the confidence to do all of this,' IBM Chief Executive Arvind Krishna says. International Business Machine Corp.'s acquisition of software company Red Hat last year helps underpin the technology and economics behind IBM's decision to restructure.

title: Nikola Highlights Its Hydrogen Efforts as Tech Questions Linger
summary: Executive discusses company's plans for future fuel cell and fueling station technology at industry conference. An executive at electric-truck company Nikola Corp. gave the hydrogen industry a closer look at the company's prototypes and plans Thursday amid questions over its technology.

title: Stimulus Talks Resume, but a Deal Remains Elusive
summary: House Speaker Pelosi ties airline aid to a broader package. WASHINGTON-Democratic and White House negotiators resumed discussions over a sweeping coronavirus relief deal Thursday, but gave no indication they were closer to a breakthrough in resolving deep-seated disputes that led President Trump to end the negotiations earlier this week.

title: NYPD Officers Kill Shooting Suspect After He Fires on Them
summary: The man was wanted for the non-fatal shooting of four people, police say. New York Police Department officers fatally shot a man in Queens on Thursday after he fired a handgun at them, as they tried to arrest him for his alleged role in a separate shooting, police officials said.

title: Citadel Securities to Buy NYSE Market-Making Unit of IMC
summary: Deal would solidify Citadel Securities' status as exchange's top designated market maker, potentially raising concentration concerns. Electronic trading giant Citadel Securities will bolster its already huge presence at the New York Stock Exchange by buying the NYSE market-making business of smaller rival IMC Financial Markets, the companies said.

title: Why Do We Bob for Apples, Not for Pears?
summary: The way gas is distributed inside a piece of fruit determines whether it sinks or floats. Fall is here and so are the traditions that cheer everyone up as the days get shorter, like bobbing for apples. I've never done this myself, but I've always been curious about why it's limited to apples. We have lots of apple trees here in the U.K., but we also have lots of native pear trees. Why doesn't anyone go pear-bobbing?

title: Unemployment Claims in New York Region Plateau
summary: New York City is still hardest hit area, with 1.9 million residents seeking jobless benefits since mid-March. First-time unemployment benefits across the Tri-State region totaled nearly 95,000 last week as rising coronavirus cases raised concerns about deeper economic pain to come.

title: Court Blocks Wisconsin's Deadline Extension for Mail-In Ballots
summary: Divided court's ruling that ballots must be received by Election Day could have implications for turnout in battleground state. A divided federal appeals court ruled that mail-in ballots in Wisconsin must be received by Election Day, blocking a trial-court order that had provided a six-day extension in light of continuing coronavirus concerns.

title: U.S. Budget Gap Tripled in Fiscal 2020 as Government Battled Pandemic
summary: Annual U.S. deficit totaled $3.1 trillion in fiscal 2020, 15.2% of GDP, Congressional Budget Office said. WASHINGTON-The U.S. budget deficit tripled in the fiscal year ended Sept. 30, the Congressional Budget Office estimated Thursday, as the government battled a global pandemic that plunged the country into a recession.

title: Morgan Stanley to Acquire Eaton Vance for $7 Billion
summary: Deal continues bank's shift away from trading toward steadier, simpler businesses like money management. Morgan Stanley said it is buying fund manager Eaton Vance Corp. for $7 billion, continuing the Wall Street firm's shift toward safer businesses like money management.

title: New U.S. Coronavirus Cases Top 50,000 for the First Time in Five Days
summary: Increases occur in states that made progress in curbing Covid-19 infections over the summer. The daily total of new coronavirus cases continued to climb in the U.S., including in states that made strides over the summer in curtailing infections.

title: WarnerMedia Plans Thousands of Job Cuts in Restructuring
summary: Changes at owner of HBO, Warner Bros. seek to cut costs by up to 20% as coronavirus pandemic pressures film and TV business. AT&T Inc.'s WarnerMedia is restructuring its workforce as it seeks to reduce costs by as much as 20% as the coronavirus pandemic drains income from movie tickets, cable subscriptions and television ads, according to people familiar with the matter.

title: Takeda, Other Firms Test Covid-19 Convalescent-Plasma Treatment
summary: NIH funds study of high antibody concentrations combined with the antiviral remdesivir. The National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases said a group of companies including Japanese drugmaker Takeda Pharmaceutical Co. began testing an experimental treatment for hospitalized Covid-19 patients that is derived from the convalescent plasma of people who have recovered from the new coronavirus.

title: U.S. Appeals Injunction Halting TikTok Ban
summary: Trump administration views the Chinese video-sharing app as a threat to national security. WASHINGTON-The Trump administration is appealing a federal court injunction blocking it from imposing a download ban on TikTok, the Chinese-owned video-sharing app that the government contends poses a national-security threat.

title: Shaq, MLK's Son, Former Disney Executives Team Up to Create SPAC
summary: Forest Road Acquisition plans to make deals in media and tech sectors. Three former high-ranking Walt Disney Co. executives are teaming up with basketball legend Shaquille O'Neal and one of Martin Luther King Jr.'s sons to make acquisitions in the media and technology industries.

title: Companies Raise Inability-to-Pay Claims Amid Pandemic, Justice Department Official Says
summary: Some companies have claimed they can't pay a full criminal penalty amid the recession caused by the coronavirus, the official says. Recent Justice Department guidance on how prosecutors should handle claims by companies that say they can't pay a criminal penalty has taken on new relevance in light of the economic downturn caused by the coronavirus pandemic.

title: Morgan Stanley Finds Money in the Cushion
summary: Developments in Washington left Morgan Stanley with a sizable capital cushion. Using that capacity to buy Eaton Vance, even fully priced, is better than many alternatives.. Morgan Stanley 's deal to acquire Eaton Vance isn't a steal. It still might prove to be a very good business decision.

title: Those Hong Kong Arrested Were Fleeing Bail
summary: No jurisdiction in the world would or could agree that an attempted escape from criminal liability is acceptable or upholds the rule of law.. Your editorial "No Escape From Hong Kong" (Oct. 1) ignores basic facts, not least that the 12 Hong Kong suspects were arrested by authorities in Guangdong Province for illegally crossing the boundary. Their case has nothing to do with freedom to travel.

title: Stocks Climb to Highest Level Since Early September
summary: Stimulus still faces hurdles; weekly jobless claims came in slightly higher than economists expected. U.S. stocks edged higher Thursday, climbing to their highest levels since early September.

title: FDA Warns Mask-Cleaner Battelle Over Inadequate Reporting
summary: Batelle's mask-decontamination system, awarded federal contract worth hundreds of millions of dollars, has triggered worries from health-care workers. The Food and Drug Administration has issued an accountability warning to a federal contractor that received a deal worth hundreds of millions of dollars to disinfect used N95 masks for health-care workers.

title: Inside the Competition to Safeguard the Internet
summary: Entrants were asked to design encryption algorithms that they think could withstand a cyberattack from a quantum computer. Hundreds of the world's top cryptographers are involved in a competition to develop new encryption standards for the U.S. to guard against classical and quantum-computing cyberattacks.

title: 'Time': Portrait of a Matriarch on Fire
summary: Garrett Bradley's documentary celebrates transformation, perseverance, and a decadeslong commitment to the pursuit of justice.. Garrett Bradley's "Time," which truly is about time, makes its abstract subject tangible, even corporeal. This powerful, poetic documentary, opening in select theaters in advance of its Oct. 16 launch on Amazon Prime Video, follows the life of a loving family, all of them doing time in their fashion.

title: 'The Right Stuff' Review: A Space Race Re-Entry
summary: Inspired by the book and film of the same name, a series on Disney+ offers a middling retelling of the Mercury space missions of the 1960s.. It's unlikely that any new take on "The Right Stuff" would fully escape the gravitational pull of Philip Kaufman's 1983 big-screen epic, which made sweeping statements about America and stars of its cast (which included Ed Harris, Sam Shepard, Dennis Quaid and Scott Glenn). The new adaptation of Tom Wolfe's 1979 nonfiction novel lacks the grandeur of Mr. Kaufman's Oscar-winner and, by every indication, its budget.

title: Debate Over Debates Draws Attention to Nonpartisan Commission
summary: The organization has overseen more than 30 presidential and vice-presidential debates since 1988. WASHINGTON-The nation's presidential debate commission has been thrust into a debate over debates.

title: 'Twelve Angry Men': First Deliberations
summary: The initial 1954 teleplay outshines the movie and stage adaptations that followed.. Most people know "Twelve Angry Men," in which Reginald Rose dramatized the contentious deliberations of a New York jury, from Sidney Lumet's 1957 film version, whose screenplay was written by Rose and which featured a top-flight ensemble cast led by Henry Fonda, Martin Balsam, Lee J. Cobb, E.G. Marshall and Jack Klugman. More recently, the Roundabout Theatre Company brought Rose's stage adaptation of "Twelve Angry Men" to Broadway in 2004 for a successful run. To this day it is a regional-theater staple, as well as the sixth most frequently staged full-length play in American high schools (where it is performed with women in the cast and is known as "Twelve Angry Jurors").

title: 'The Forty-Year-Old Version' Review: A Midlife Reinvention
summary: Radha Blank directs, writes, produces and stars in a Netflix film about an unsuccessful playwright who makes the unlikely decision to become a rapper.. Forty is the new 90, judging by "The Forty-Year-Old Version." Its aging wunderkind is fast approaching the four-decade mark and having an existential crisis of epic proportions; viewers of even riper vintage will wonder if they shouldn't just lie down and assume the fetal position. At the same time, the film belies every message it pretends to send about age: Radha Blank not only plays a lead role that's at least partly autobiographical, but also wrote, produced and directed the film, and proves herself a potent screen presence/comic actress in her directorial debut. She also displays an instinct about capturing New York that suggests Woody Allen at his most Manhattan-esque. Though certainly without the Cole Porter.

title: How Citadel CEO Ken Griffin Built a $1 Billion Private Property Portfolio
summary: Resume Subscription. In the early 1900s, the country's wealthiest businessmen including William Randolph Hearst and John D. Rockefeller built sprawling, gilded estates. Living at that kind of boundless scale fell out of favor with subsequent generations, however, and these kinds of estates were either subdivided or turned over to the state or to preservationists.

title: 'Totally Under Control' Review: Flunking the Covid Test
summary: A new documentary from Alex Gibney, Ophelia Harutyunyan and Suzanne Hillinger is an up-to-the-minute accounting of America's failures in the fight against coronavirus.. Sometimes the simplest way to start a review is with a description of how the movie starts. In the case of "Totally Under Control," opening in select drive-in theaters ahead of a streaming launch later this month, it's risking no spoilers to reveal how the documentary ends-with these words on a black screen: "One day after the completion of this film, President Donald Trump revealed that he had tested positive for Covid-19."

title: U.S. Sanctions Additional Iranian Banks
summary: Move aims to sever few financial connections Tehran still has to world. WASHINGTON-The Trump administration Thursday blacklisted 18 Iranian banks that remain unsanctioned under its economywide pressure campaign.

title: The Cybersecurity Frontier
summary: Resume Subscription. Published Oct. 8, 2020 4:09 pm ET

title: Brands Face a New Online Threat: Disinformation Attacks
summary: For years cybersecurity has focused on technical problems, but social-media campaigns to spread bad information about companies is an emerging issue. Author

title: Insurance Executive Ordered to Prison on Seven-Year Sentence
summary: Greg Lindberg asks judge to delay imprisonment. Convicted insurance executive Greg Lindberg has been ordered to report to federal prison on Oct. 20 to begin serving a sentence of more than seven years for attempted bribery of North Carolina's elected insurance commissioner, according to a court filing.

title: Speed-Reading Apps to Max Out Your Quarantine Downtime
summary: These apps update old-school tricks, helping train your eyes and brain so you can zip through text-though critics question whether the skills stay with you. PAPERBACKS STACKED high on your nightstand, e-books lingering in your Amazon carts, articles left unread in your browser-at this point it's too much material for a normal human lifetime. Several apps and technologies, however, can help you plow through the pages you've piled up (with the best intentions) during quarantine, in far less time.

title: Peak Oil? OPEC Says the World's Richest Countries Are Already There
summary: It expects demand in most developed countries to fall by about 27% over next 25 years, according to annual survey. The world's thirst for oil is unlikely to peak for two more decades but may already have crested in the U.S. and other wealthier countries, according to a forecast by OPEC.

title: Republican Fundraiser Expected to Plead Guilty to Violating Foreign Lobbying Law, Sources Say
summary: Elliott Broidy allegedly lobbied for Jho Low, the accused mastermind of 1MDB scandal and was paid at least $6 million to influence U.S. investigation, say prosecutors. Republican fundraiser Elliott Broidy is expected to plead guilty to violating a foreign lobbying law, according to people familiar with the matter, the latest development in a sprawling investigation into a multibillion-dollar alleged fraud at a Malaysian fund that has ensnared a cast of characters, from Goldman Sachs Group Inc. to a rap star.

title: Bestselling Books Week Ended October 3
summary: With data from NPD BookScan.

title: Joe Biden: The Economic Growth Candidate?
summary: It's hard to see how Joe Biden's tax plan would grow anything except the government.. Regarding Jason Furman's "Biden's Tax Plan Would Spur Economic Growth" (op-ed, Oct. 6): What Mr. Furman fails to prove is the idea that state redistribution of resources grows the pool of real resources. Clearly the proposal increases GDP, which arbitrarily records government spending as growth.

title: Stimulus Check Update: What Happens Next?
summary: After halting stimulus talks, President Trump called on Congress to pass individual coronavirus relief measures, but House Speaker Nancy Pelosi has pushed back. President Trump halted talks with Democrats about a Covid-19 stimulus package earlier this week, instead pushing for individual relief bills, including aid for airlines and another round of direct checks to many U.S. households. House Speaker Nancy Pelosi (D., Calif.) has now signaled she wouldn't support a stand-alone airline relief bill without a broader coronavirus aid package.

title: Mr. Saturday Night
summary: Eddie Van Halen was a creative force who played it loud.. For millions of people around the world, weekends will feel a little less lively without Eddie Van Halen, who died of cancer this week at age 65. The virtuoso guitarist may not have been a model citizen, but he was a creative innovator who brought raucous joy to generations of fans.

title: Trans-Racial Adoption and Helping Children
summary: Outcomes such as behavior, school performance, mental health, self esteem, and adult racial identity formation don't statistically differ between black children adopted by white parents and those adopted by black parents.. Jason L. Riley's "The Left's Unhealthy Interest in Amy Coney Barrett's Adopted Kids" (Upward Mobility, Sept. 30) cites a part of our 2018 book that summarized the evidence on the effects of transracial adoption. Outcomes such as behavior, school performance, mental health, self esteem and adult racial-identity formation don't statistically differ between black children adopted by white parents and those adopted by black parents. But, as Mr. Riley points out, the adoption of two Haitian children by Amy Coney Barrett has stimulated activists on the left, including Ibram X. Kendi, to speak, or tweet, in opposition to such adoptions.

title: My Recent Postal Ballot Was the Best I've Ever Cast
summary: I sat at my computer and researched every candidate, every issue and made much better choices than I ever could have made in a voting booth.. This year, I executed the best vote I have ever completed. Even if you don't agree with my choices, you would certainly agree that it was an excellent vote. On my ballot there were judgeships at risk, state constitutional amendments to consider, city council seats I had never heard of, state representatives and a whole plethora of people I had never heard of or from. Yet I was expected to vote for or against them. I sat quietly at my computer with a cup of coffee and researched every single candidate, every single issue and made much better choices than I ever could have made in a voting booth. There may or may not be significant fraud associated with mail-in voting, but overall I felt better about my vote than I have at any time during my 50-plus-year voting history. Furthermore, I was given the means to track my vote online, so I have confidence that this system is worth perfecting, flaws and all ("Errors Seen in Mail-in Ballots," U.S. News, Oct. 5).

title: Mohammad-Reza Shajarian, a Paragon of Persian Music, Dies at 80
summary: The singer, who became revered for his swooping, undulating voice, united Iranians across generations. When Mohammad-Reza Shajarian, Iran's most celebrated contemporary singer, threw his widespread popularity behind pro-democracy protesters in 2009, he was neither arrested nor forced to flee the country like many of his countrymen.

title: New York City's Outdoor Dining Isn't Advantageous to All Restaurants
summary: Many don't have viable outdoor space compliant with the city's rules. When New York City recently said that restaurants could offer outdoor dining year-round, it was a decision these establishments quickly lauded. But for Roni Mazumdar, who owns Indian restaurants in the city, the news was a harsh reminder that the playing field isn't the same for every dining spot.

title: IBM to Spin Off Services Unit to Accelerate Cloud-Computing Pivot
summary: The new public company would be a lower-margin business with growth potential, IBM CEO says. International Business Machines Corp. is planning its biggest-ever business exit, spinning off a major part of its information-technology services operations to accelerate the 109-year-old tech pioneer's focus on faster-growing businesses like cloud-computing and artificial intelligence.

title: An American Coup Attempt
summary: Time may be running out to expose the effort to overthrow Trump, which began before his election.. The U.S. is in a constitutional crisis. It began on the day of President Trump's election, when unelected bureaucrats mobilized against his presidency. This is a crisis in the executive branch, perpetrated by subordinate officials who don't see themselves as answerable to the president. They have effectively established a fourth branch of government-a permanent, unaccountable bureaucracy.

title: The Trump Treatment for Covid Is Coming Soon
summary: Antibody drugs like the one the president took may be a bridge to a vaccine.. President Trump has been criticized for receiving experimental Covid-19 treatments that aren't available to ordinary Americans. But man-made antibodies like those Mr. Trump received may soon be rolled out for broader public use. Such treatments may be a bridge to a vaccine.

title: Fed's Rosengren Says Pre-Pandemic Risk Taking Will Likely Slow Recovery Effort
summary: Boston Fed leader opposed Fed's 2019 rate-cuts, and says the consequences of easy-money stance are playing out now. Federal Reserve Bank of Boston leader Eric Rosengren on Thursday renewed his longstanding concern that long periods of very low interest rates can exacerbate economic troubles when a downturn arrives.

title: Russia's Siberian Waters See Record Ship Traffic as Ice Melt Accelerates
summary: The Northern Sea Route is becoming a highway to move Russia's oil and natural gas exports while some global carriers shy away. The Arctic has gone through its warmest summer on record, and with the ice melting, more ships than ever are sailing along Russia's Siberian coast, underscoring its role as a growing energy transport corridor and potential as a new ocean trade route.

title: New York Should Have Done More Outreach in Covid-19 Hot Spots Before Surges, Community Leaders Say
summary: Gov. Cuomo has ordered new restrictions on communities where the coronavirus has rebounded. This summer New York City's public-hospital system identified the areas most at risk of a resurgence of Covid-19 and enlisted community-based organizations to help educate residents and test and trace for the virus.

title: The Newly Trendy Sofa That Will Change the Way You Live
summary: Weary of L-shapes and inspired by Covid-19, designers turn to the 'C Sofa,' a semicircular sectional where socializing and social distancing can coexist. THE COUPLE first spotted the sinuous sofa in the lobby of the King David Hotel in Jerusalem in the 1970s. There on a family trip from New York, they couldn't get the curved 17.5-foot sectional-a $25,000 piece tufted in segments like a caterpillar and named "Non Stop" by Swiss furniture brand de Sede-out of their minds.

title: The Power of Telling Stories in Pictures
summary: 'Peanuts' turns 70 this month, but the origins of narrative art go back to ancient Sumeria more than 4,000 years ago.. Good grief! It's Snoopy's 70th birthday. Charles M. Schulz's 'Peanuts' comic strip made its debut on Oct. 2, 1950, and though it ended with Schulz's death in 2000, Snoopy, Charlie Brown, Lucy and their friends are still beloved today. Their longevity is a testament to the power of the comic strip-a form of storytelling that has been around for thousands of years.

title: Judges Revive Conviction of Hunter Biden's Ex-Business Partner
summary: Devon Archer to be sentenced on securities fraud and conspiracy charges. A federal appeals court reinstated the conviction of a former business associate of Hunter Biden on securities fraud and conspiracy charges, ruling a lower-court judge erred last year in vacating a jury's verdict.

title: SoftBank-Backed Greensill Looks to Raise Fresh Capital
summary: Supply-chain finance company says business is booming, but it also faces client defaults, regulatory scrutiny and loosening ties from partner firms. LONDON- SoftBank Group Corp. -backed Greensill Capital, a provider of specialty finance that helps companies manage cash, said it is asking investors for fresh capital to bolster its balance sheet.

title: Facebook Removes Network Tied to Conservative Group Over Fake Accounts
summary: Accounts were run by marketing firm working on behalf of Turning Point USA and another client. Facebook Inc. said it removed a network of accounts with links to a U.S. conservative political youth group for posing as fake users to praise President Trump and criticize his Democratic rival, Joe Biden.

title: Number Puzzles
Saudis Consider Canceling OPEC Plans to Boost Output
summary: Kingdom sees rising Covid-19 cases around the world depressing demand. Saudi Arabia is considering canceling OPEC plans for an oil output hike early next year, senior Saudi oil advisers said, as Covid-19 cases in many parts of the world rise and the expected return of Libyan crude threatens to swell global supplies.

title: A Better Way to Cook Beans: Tips From a Chef's Playbook
summary: These simple moves will make your next pot of beans exponentially more delicious. Put the tips to the test in a recipe for cozy, comforting beans and greens on toast.. I OWE MY love of beans largely to Sara Kramer. Now chef/partner at Kismet, in Los Angeles, Sara was the chef at Glasserie, in Brooklyn, when I worked with her there. Before that, I had tried cooking beans every which way, from wood-fired ovens to pressure cookers, all of which failed to render them exciting. Sara taught me it only takes a couple smart moves to give beans some depth and even a dash of drama.

title: 'R' Is for Recovery, but What Kind?
summary: If the letters V and K can describe our financial fate, why not Q or S or X?. During the first presidential debate, moderator Chris Wallace tried to get Donald Trump and Joe Biden to explain the difference between a "V-shaped" economic recovery and a "K-shaped" recovery. The inquiry didn't lead anywhere productive, but the subject is still very important. Especially to a nation where most of us had never heard of a K-shaped recovery before.

title: Vaccine-Trial Volunteers Look to Make a Difference
summary: Stakes are high as participants aim to help people return to their normal lives-and persuade skeptics of vaccines. Victoria Smith had lost three patients to Covid-19, while another patient had lost her husband and brother to the virus. So when the New Orleans-area family physician learned in July that her health system would participate in a vaccine trial, she was in the lab to get her first dose the next day.

title: Remote Schooling Is the New First-Class Hotel Perk
summary: Poolside classrooms, in-person tutors, and a host of cushy extracurricular activities-these resorts are turning distance-learning into a luxury amenity. AS WITH MANY parents this school year, mother-of-two Shannon Baker Meyer is constantly juggling work and distance-learning for her two kids. Through an online happy hour with girlfriends, Ms. Baker Meyer, the president of a communications agency in Pittsburgh, heard about Kimpton Hotel Monaco Pittsburgh's virtual learning package for parents and booked a one-night staycation to test it out. She and her 7-year-old daughter, Harper, had adjoining rooms (day use of an extra room starts at $75), each with their own desk setup. Greg Goffin, the hotel's newly appointed Chief Virtual Learning Officer (he doubles as the hotel's director of sales and marketing), helped Harper set up the Zoom call with her classroom on the hotel computer, supplied Animal Crackers and organic juice boxes and fetched colored paper and crayons for an art project when she realized she'd forgotten hers-freeing up Ms. Baker-Meyer to focus on her own work.

title: North Korea Loves Military Parades-Will Kim Jong Un Bring Out the Big Guns?
summary: Country to mark 75th Workers' Party anniversary with nuclear talks at a standstill ahead of U.S. election. SEOUL-North Korea's first military parade in two years is expected to feature throngs of spectators and plenty of propaganda, but the most closely watched element will be what, if any, new weapons leader Kim Jong Un puts on display for the world.

title: The Tennessee Titans' Continued Outbreak Threatens the NFL's Schedule
summary: Another positive result inside the team on Thursday casts doubt on if the team will play Sunday-and how the league will handle it. The still-growing Covid-19 outbreak inside the Tennessee Titans is on the verge of disrupting another of the team's games, creating a scheduling nightmare for the NFL's pandemic season with no easy fix.

title: During a Zoom Frog Dissection, Students Posted Vomit Emojis. Welcome to the Virtual Field Trip.
summary: The pandemic has put traditional school outings on hold, so students are taking virtual field trips; meet the polar bear online. On a recent virtual field trip run by the Denver Museum of Nature & Science, an instructor talked via Zoom about the digestive system before switching over to her "dissection camera." A dead frog, rendered yellow and rubbery by chemicals, popped up on the screen.

title: Hackers Eye Their Next Targets, From Schools to Cars
summary: Systems that are secure today may not be tomorrow. Here's what cybersecurity experts say could be a future focus for attacks.. Author

title: Unemployment Claims Remain Historically High
summary: Initial claims for jobless benefits show pandemic continues to batter labor market. U.S. unemployment claims remained elevated above pre-pandemic highs last week, as layoffs persist and the labor-market recovery flashes signs of slowdown.

title: Will This Bubble Go K-Pop?
summary: Korean boy band sees huge demand for IPO, but it was outsold by a videogame company. By almost any standard, the level of enthusiasm for Big Hit Entertainment was extraordinary.

title: Is the Supreme Court Too Catholic?
summary: From Antonin Scalia to Amy Coney Barrett, opposition to Catholic nominees has been mainly about the politics of abortion, not their religious faith. 'The conclusion one draws is that the dogma lives loudly within you. And that's of concern." So said Sen. Dianne Feinstein to Amy Coney Barrett during her confirmation hearings for a seat on the Seventh Circuit Court of Appeals in 2017. Brian Buescher, now a federal district judge in Nebraska, faced similar questioning in 2018 from Sen. Mazie Hirono and Sen. Kamala Harris, who asked him to distance himself from the Knights of Columbus, a Catholic men's fraternal and charitable organization, because the Knights have devoted some of their resources to political causes such as opposition to abortion and same-sex marriage.

title: 5 Intimidating Wines That Are Actually Easy to Love
summary: Our wine columnist polled oenophiles on the wines they find most challenging. Then she selected examples so delicious, they sway even the skittish.. WHEN I POLLED friends a few months ago on wines they consider "easygoing," I was surprised how many of them offered the same examples. But when I began reporting this column on "challenging" wines, each person I consulted put forward a different one. A single certainty united them, however: A challenging wine is one to avoid.

title: Health Coverage Costs Continued Steady Rise Pre-Pandemic
summary: Employers hold deductibles at 2019 levels, survey shows.. The average cost of employer health coverage surpassed $21,000 for a family plan this year, according to a new survey, a rise reflecting rates calculated before the pandemic upended normal patterns of medical care.

title: Raymond Carey Ran ADT and Raised Alarms About Wall Street
summary: CEO criticized focus on short-term earnings and favored sharing more of the profit with employees.

title: WSJ Survey: 43% of Economists Don't See U.S. Gaining Back Lost Jobs Until 2023
summary: They cite continued spread of coronavirus, and uncertainty surrounding stimulus package, election outcome. The U.S. labor market faces a protracted recovery amid the continued spread of the coronavirus and uncertainty over prospects for another stimulus package and the outcome of the presidential election, according to a new Wall Street Journal survey of economists.

title: Kenzo Takada Helped Put Asia on Global Fashion Map
summary: Japan-born designer flourished in Paris and favored jungle prints and loose silhouettes. Before Kenzo, it was hard for many in the fashion world to imagine an Asian designer at the top of Paris haute couture. After Kenzo, Asian talent drawing inspiration from the East and beyond transformed the industry.

title: There's No Oil in Wisconsin. The Fracking Bust Hit It Anyway.

title: Cities Are Losing Police Chiefs and Struggling to Hire New Ones
summary: Political pressure and budget cuts have made the job less appealing, experienced officers say, as cities seek fresh leaders to signal change. This summer, a headhunter called Lashinda Stair, second-in-command at the Detroit Police Department, and asked if she was interested in potentially becoming the chief of the Louisville Metro Police Department. Her answer: "Absolutely not."

title: Putin Loses His Footing in Russia's Backyard
summary: Resume Subscription. MOSCOW-A series of crises in Russia's neighbors is upending the Kremlin's plans for deeper economic and defense ties with the former Soviet republics, leaving a vacuum for regional competitors such as China and Turkey to exploit.

title: This Year, Embrace the Magical Power of Dressing Up
summary: Slick reds, ethereal purples, strong silvers and fairylike feathers transport dresses to an otherworldly, unforgettable place. There's something about this year that has made dressing up feel like an escape mechanism. If you're stuck inside for the time being, at least your clothes can take you somewhere else. Take for example, the above image of model Fadhi Mohamed. Creating a bold look with a long slick of scarlet is your ticket out of dreamland and into fashion history. For this shoot, photographer Campbell Addy and Stylist Clare Richardson put together a set of looks that's not only fashion forward, but that can transport you to another realm entirely. Let their ethereal work-the jaw-dropping plays with volume, the shimmer of metallics and the surprise of a vintage moment-inspire your sartorial decisions for the upcoming season. Your social calendar might not be filled up right now, but these looks are vibrant enough to make you feel like you're red carpet ready. Check out all of the whimsical shots below.

title: IBM, Regeneron, Lilly: What to Watch When the Stock Market Opens Today
summary: The S&P 500 is poised for a second day of gains as investors remain optimistic about government-spending plans targeted at airlines and other parts of the economy.. Here's what we are watching as markets kick into gear Thursday.

title: Derek Chauvin, Ex-Officer Charged in George Floyd Killing, Released on Bail
summary: Also Wednesday, a Wisconsin district attorney found police officer was justified in February shooting death of teenager. Derek Chauvin, the former Minneapolis police officer charged with second-degree murder for the death of George Floyd during a May 25 arrest, was released from custody Wednesday after posting a $1 million bond.

title: Harvard Spins Out Natural-Resources Team, Ending Long Chapter at Endowment
summary: Spinout of Solum shrinks the $41.9 billion endowment's controversial natural-resources portfolio. Harvard University's endowment has spun out its natural-resources team into an independent investment firm that will take over some of the endowment's portfolio of orchards, farms and plantations.

title: American Poet Louise Glück Awarded Nobel Prize in Literature
summary: Swedish Academy awards prize to poet 'for her unmistakable poetic voice that with austere beauty makes individual existence universal'. American poet Louise Glück won the Nobel Prize in Literature on Thursday for what the judges described as "her unmistakable poetic voice that with austere beauty makes individual existence universal."

title: McDonald's Boosts Sales With Drive-Throughs and Travis Scott
summary: Burger giant is adding menu items, marketing partnerships as pandemic keeps many dining rooms closed. McDonald's Corp. said its U.S. sales have bounced back from the initial shock of the coronavirus pandemic, thanks to sped-up drive-throughs and a meal promotion with musician Travis Scott.

title: Saudi Staycations Lay Bare Obstacles to Kingdom's Tourism Drive
summary: With international travel constrained, many Saudi residents are exploring the kingdom; most attractions lack basic infrastructure. UMLUJ, Saudi Arabia-Ahmad Hamid usually spends his summers partying in London nightclubs. Stranded at home in Jeddah this year because of the coronavirus pandemic, he and his friends opted instead to vacation a short drive away in this ancient village on the Red Sea coast.

title: Where Trump and Biden Stand on Mortgage Finance
summary: The incumbent administration eyes returning Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac to private ownership. Democrats would use them to promote affordable housing.. title: How to Protect Household Staff, and the Household, From Covid
summary: Homeowners need to implement-and enforce-safety protocols to shield family members and staffers alike. Is your housekeeper going to kill you? Or could you be the killer?

title: Banks' Arctic Financing Retreat Rattles Oil Industry
summary: A pledge by some banks not to fund Arctic drilling has sparked a pushback by allies of the oil-and-gas industry who fear such bans could spread. Defenders of the oil-and-gas industry in Washington are fighting back against big banks who want to stop financing new Arctic-drilling projects, fearing it could be a harbinger of an unbankable future for fossil-fuel companies.

title: The 2020 Sports Season Counts. No Asterisks, No Questions.
summary: This is a year of strange pandemic championships, but those trophies are just as valid as all the ones that came before.. This is a strange sports year, to say the least-Rafael Nadal is sliding around the Parisian red dirt in the second week of October; the Masters tees off in November; college football is even more bonkers than usual-and there's been some wonderment as to whether or not championships earned in 2020 should, you know, count as much as they usually do:

title: Hydrogen's Dirty Little Secret
summary: Most of this emission-free gas is currently produced using fossil fuels, and a lot of work is required to clean it up. Despite all the hype over green hydrogen, most of the gas supplied now is decidedly not green. The path to cleaning it up is long.

title: Exxon Could Get a Chemical Turbo Boost if Oil Rebounds
summary: Higher crude prices could magnify chemicals segment's earnings because of the company's exposure to North America and Middle East. title: Moderna Vows to Not Enforce Covid-19 Vaccine Patents During Pandemic
summary: The company is also willing to license the technology behind its experimental coronavirus vaccine. Moderna Inc. said it wouldn't enforce patents related to its experimental Covid-19 vaccine while the pandemic continues and is willing to license the patents to others after the pandemic.

title: Big Tech Buyout Fantasies May Be on Hold
summary: Government's ambitious case against tech giants faces many hurdles, but curbing M&A activity seems certain. While much remains uncertain about the federal government's ambitious case against big tech, at least one outcome seems highly likely: Tech giants won't be able to buy their way to growth anytime soon.

title: A Quick and Delicious Fall Dinner Made for Dipping
summary: From Khao Noodle Shop in Dallas, this recipe for pork patties and rice with cucumbers, cilantro and a chile-vinegar dipping sauce is fast, fresh and incredibly fun to eat. LONG BEFORE Donny Sirisavath taught himself to cook, decades before he left his day job as an engineer at Hewlett-Packard to open his own restaurant, Khao Noodle Shop, in Dallas, this was his comfort food. "When I was younger, I'd just eat pork patties and rice," he said. His mother cooked it for his family and other Laotian refugees in their community. "She is at the heart and soul of my cooking," he said.

title: Samsung's Blowout Quarter is the Flipside of Huawei's Woes
summary: But not all of the good bad news will last. Call it Samsung 's schadenfreude quarter: The company's blowout results owe a lot to the travails of Chinese rival Huawei. Not all of the good bad news will last, however.

title: The Vice Presidential Debate: The Moments That Mattered
summary: Vice President Mike Pence and Sen. Kamala Harris clash over coronavirus, economy and climate change. Vice President Mike Pence and Sen. Kamala Harris squared off in their first and only debate on Wednesday, sparring over the coronavirus pandemic, health care, racial-justice protests and other issues that have dominated the 2020 campaign with less than one month remaining until the November election.

title: Startup CFOs Get Some Help From Counterparts at Venture Funds
summary: Venture finance chiefs are providing guidance to executives at portfolio companies dealing with pandemic-related stresses. Finance chiefs at some startups are turning to their venture-fund counterparts for guidance during the coronavirus pandemic, which for some executives triggered the first economic crisis in their professional lives.

title: Wells Fargo CEO Finds Himself on Defense After a Tough First Year
summary: Charles Scharf began the job focused on making peace with regulators. Now he has a recession and a morale problem on his hands.. A long list of challenges confronted Wells Fargo & Co. Chief Executive Charles Scharf when he was brought in to restore the bank's tarnished reputation. In the year since, his problems have only multiplied.

summary: Many wonder where to find the best place for their savings. Many Americans are saving more than ever before during the pandemic, but the Federal Reserve's long-term low rates have many wondering: Where is the best place to store cash?

summary: Here's what to know and how to adjust your financial plan if you take a buyout offer. A growing number of companies are offering workers cash this year to walk away from their jobs-a daunting prospect in a recession.

summary: A survey shows 90% of companies say they have experienced new or amplified risks related to the pandemic. Companies are facing new and amplified compliance risks at a time when the coronavirus pandemic has made many compliance programs less effective, a new survey found.

title: Dollar General to Open Stores Aimed at Wealthier Shoppers
summary: New Popshelf chain to carry party supplies, beauty products and home decor in big-city suburbs. Dollar General Corp. , the rapidly growing discount chain with over 16,300 stores dotting the rural American landscape, wants to attract more high-income shoppers looking to splurge.

summary: Among the possible scenarios: Fewer projects. And the projects that get done will be at a higher price.. title: Chinese Fintech Company Lufax Plans U.S. IPO
summary: Online lending and investment firm could raise about $3 billion, according to a person familiar with the situation. One of China's largest financial-technology companies, Lufax Holding Ltd., is planning an initial public offering in the U.S., even as some other Chinese companies are opting to sell stock closer to home.

title: JPMorgan Unveils Push to Bridge Racial Wealth Gap
summary: Bank focuses on expanding access to affordable housing and boosting minority-owned small businesses. JPMorgan Chase & Co. said it would extend billions of dollars in additional loans to Black and Latino home buyers and small-business owners as part of a push to narrow America's racial wealth gap.

title: Samsung Forecasts Highest Operating Profits in Two Years
summary: The company, a bellwether for global tech industry, has seen sales bounce back in its smartphones and consumer electronics divisions. SEOUL- Samsung Electronics Co. said it expects around 12.3 trillion won ($10.6 billion) in operating profits for the third quarter, rising on the same period a year earlier and driven by stronger smartphone and consumer electronics sales, as companies adapt to the pandemic's effects long-term.

title: Hurricane Delta Churns Through Gulf Toward Coastal Louisiana
summary: After lashing Mexico's Caribbean resort towns, storm could hit part of Gulf Coast still recovering from Laura. Residents of coastal Louisiana, who were pounded by Hurricane Laura in late August, are preparing for another major hurricane that is headed their way.

title: Mike Pence's Re-Election Case
summary: He told voters facts about the Biden agenda they haven't heard.. The pre- and post-debate spin about Wednesday's clash of vice-presidential candidates from the left was that it's merely a sideshow. They say the appearance of rhetorical norms is an illusion with Donald Trump at the top of the ticket. But Mike Pence and Kamala Harris did a public service by offering a contrast on issues and values that voters aren't getting from the media or the presidential candidates.

title: Trump Says He Wants All Troops in Afghanistan Home by Christmas, Going Further Than Security Adviser
summary: Robert O'Brien said earlier Wednesday that 2,500 troops would stay in Afghanistan after the end of the year. WASHINGTON-President Trump tweeted late Wednesday that all American troops should be out of Afghanistan by Christmas, a new goal post for ending the long-running conflict that caught his own Pentagon flat-footed.

title: Eli Lilly Asks FDA to Authorize Covid-19 Antibody Drug
summary: Company says it could supply one million doses of the treatment this year if emergency use is allowed. Eli Lilly & Co. said it has requested U.S. authorization for the emergency use of an experimental antibody-based treatment for people with recently diagnosed, mild-to-moderate Covid-19, a move that could open the door to a new class of coronavirus treatments capable of helping early cases and perhaps even preventing them.

title: Trump Symptom-Free for 24 Hours, Says White House Doctor
summary: President returns to Oval Office after doctor says he has received no supplemental oxygen since leaving hospital; key details about Trump's health remain unclear. President Trump's recovery from a Covid-19 infection continued to progress, the White House's top doctor said Wednesday, even as key details about the president's health and his potential return to the campaign trail remained unclear.

title: Chicken-Industry Officials Indicted in Price-Fixing Probe
summary: New charges expand Justice Department's antitrust action in poultry industry. Six current and former chicken-industry executives were indicted on price-fixing charges, expanding the U.S. government's antitrust prosecutions in the $65 billion poultry industry.

title: Trump's Intelligence Chief Releases More Than 1,000 Pages of Documents
summary: John Ratcliffe says material is being used to support a probe of origins of investigations into Trump ties to Russia. WASHINGTON-Director of National Intelligence John Ratcliffe said on Wednesday that he has released more than 1,000 pages of documents to the Justice Department to support its probe of the origins of the Trump-Russia investigation, and he said more material might be declassified.

title: Trump Calls for Some Covid-19 Aid After Shutting Down Stimulus Talks
summary: President again seeks a series of individual bills, an approach Democrats have consistently rejected. WASHINGTON-President Trump renewed his calls for Congress to pass individual coronavirus relief measures, including airline aid to avert widespread layoffs, after he ended negotiations with Democrats on a larger package until after the election.

title: The Debate Between Pence and Harris: What Time to Watch and Key Issues
summary: President Trump's Covid-19 diagnosis could keep the coronavirus and the administration's handling of it front and center. Vice President Mike Pence and Sen. Kamala Harris, the Democratic vice presidential nominee, will face off in their first and only debate tonight amid President Trump's ongoing bout with Covid-19, which could keep the coronavirus pandemic in focus during the matchup.

title: New York City Parents Protest School Shutdowns
summary: After about 300 school closures on Tuesday, state releases map but no list of additional schools to be closed Thursday. Parents at some New York City schools shutting down because of local rises in coronavirus cases protested Gov. Andrew Cuomo's closure plans Wednesday, saying their schools are safe and their children need in-person classes.

title: Marine Corps Assistant Commandant Tests Positive for Covid-19
summary: Gen. Gary Thomas, the Marine Corps's No. 2 general, has been in self-quarantine since Oct. 6, with mild symptoms. WASHINGTON-The assistant commandant of the U.S. Marine Corps, Gen. Gary Thomas, has tested positive for Covid-19 and is in quarantine, Marine Corps officials said.

title: Facebook to Suspend U.S. Political Ads on Election Day
summary: Social-media company takes its latest step to combat potential confusion and abuse related to vote. Facebook Inc. said it would suspend indefinitely all political and social-issue advertising in the U.S. after the polls close Nov. 3, in its latest move to combat potential confusion and abuse related to the election.
